commit_message:
Revert "Add migration for new ceph fields"

This reverts commit 014734cb34f51e5d8785bcef9f7e8a998e21316e.

That commit broke our nailgun tests. E.g.,
http://logs.openstack.org/11/305811/3/check/gate-fuel-web-python27-db/f4a5fcb/console.html

2016-04-14 15:35:21.717 |     def upgrade_ceph_cluster_attrs():
2016-04-14 15:35:21.717 |         connection = op.get_bind()
2016-04-14 15:35:21.717 |     
2016-04-14 15:35:21.717 |         for cluster_id, editable in connection.execute(q_get_cluster_attrs):
2016-04-14 15:35:21.718 |             editable = jsonutils.loads(editable)
2016-04-14 15:35:21.718 | >           editable['storage'].update(ceph_storage_attrs)
2016-04-14 15:35:21.718 | E           KeyError: 'storage'

Change-Id: I08fdc13186e1fc4b0747f7c0a886c1d116c1e65d
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/fuel-web refs/changes/64/305964/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
deleted_lines: editable = { 'storage': { 'metadata': { 'label': 'Storage Backends', 'weight': 60, 'group': 'storage' } } } 'attributes_metadata': jsonutils.dumps({ 'editable': editable }) cluster_id = result.inserted_primary_key[0] db.execute( meta.tables['attributes'].insert(), [{ 'cluster_id': cluster_id, 'editable': jsonutils.dumps(editable) }]) class TestCephAttributesMigration(base.BaseAlembicMigrationTest): def test_ceph_cluster_attrs(self): ceph_opts = ['fsid', 'mon_key', 'admin_key', 'bootstrap_osd_key', 'radosgw_key'] clusters_attributes = self.meta.tables['attributes'] results = db.execute( sa.select([clusters_attributes.c.editable]) ).fetchall() for cluster_attrs_row in results: cluster_attrs = jsonutils.loads(cluster_attrs_row[0]) for ceph_opt in ceph_opts: self.assertIn(ceph_opt, cluster_attrs['storage']) self.assertIn('metadata', cluster_attrs['storage'])

subject: run_tests: uninstall epel-release
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-04-14 02:39:59.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/puppet-openstack-integration/commit/7267783ee550d4bdd1ebc82999c19f97be6a1ea3', 'message': 'run_tests: uninstall epel-release

epel-release is installed by OpenStack Infra when building images.
The problem is RDO + EPEL does not work find, there are some
dependencies issues.

This patch makes sure EPEL is not installed when we start our CI jobs.
The next steps will be to run puppet-openstack-integration with EPEL
disabled in ceph::repo, and patch ceph::repo to use centos ceph repos [1]

[1] https://bugs.launchpad.net/puppet-ceph/+bug/1562998

This patch is part of the efforts to stop using EPEL at all.

Change-Id: I506754e2c5021ee728675a8771f2e24b8576f7d5
(cherry picked from commit 625da96a42278091561b012d5441389f72c32dd6)

commit_message:
run_tests: uninstall epel-release

epel-release is installed by OpenStack Infra when building images.
The problem is RDO + EPEL does not work find, there are some
dependencies issues.

This patch makes sure EPEL is not installed when we start our CI jobs.
The next steps will be to run puppet-openstack-integration with EPEL
disabled in ceph::repo, and patch ceph::repo to use centos ceph repos [1]

[1] https://bugs.launchpad.net/puppet-ceph/+bug/1562998

This patch is part of the efforts to stop using EPEL at all.

Change-Id: I506754e2c5021ee728675a8771f2e24b8576f7d5
(cherry picked from commit 625da96a42278091561b012d5441389f72c32dd6)
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/puppet-openstack-integration refs/changes/81/305581/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # EPEL does not work fine with RDO, we need to make sure EPEL is really disabled if rpm --quiet -q epel-release; then $SUDO rpm -e epel-release fi

commit_message:
Add Unit Tests for Swift_config type

Change-Id: Ib431515f8472789def4a6dc4ab4fab97d698246f
Partial-bug: #1440401
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/puppet-swift refs/changes/04/304804/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: it 'should require a name' do expect { Puppet::Type.type(:swift_config).new({}) }.to raise_error(Puppet::Error, 'Title or name must be provided') end it 'should not expect a name with whitespace' do expect { Puppet::Type.type(:swift_config).new(:name => 'f oo') }.to raise_error(Puppet::Error, /Parameter name failed/) end it 'should fail when there is no section' do expect { Puppet::Type.type(:swift_config).new(:name => 'foo') }.to raise_error(Puppet::Error, /Parameter name failed/) end it 'should not require a value when ensure is absent' do Puppet::Type.type(:swift_config).new(:name => 'DEFAULT/foo', :ensure => :absent) end it 'should accept a valid value' do @swift_config[:value] = 'bar' expect(@swift_config[:value]).to eq('bar') end it 'should not accept a value with whitespace' do @swift_config[:value] = 'b ar' expect(@swift_config[:value]).to eq('b ar') end it 'should accept valid ensure values' do @swift_config[:ensure] = :present expect(@swift_config[:ensure]).to eq(:present) @swift_config[:ensure] = :absent expect(@swift_config[:ensure]).to eq(:absent) end it 'should not accept invalid ensure values' do expect { @swift_config[:ensure] = :latest }.to raise_error(Puppet::Error, /Invalid value/) end

commit_message:
Fix KeyError when rename to a name is already in use

When a user attempts to rename a project via the PATCH
v3/projects/{project_id} API, and the new name is already in-use, rather
than return a nice error explaining that the name is in use, keystone
blows up and raises `KeyError: 'is_domain'` in
_generate_project_name_conflict_msg.

Change-Id: I56fcd8fe1258e2d1de3e541144649ef619f86a7b
Closes-bug: #1565108

commit_message:
New api for bulk port-updates

Currently there is no api available for bulk port updates,
which takes a list of ports .
Having one will help in processing port-updates quickly as per
the specific driver implementation
For example: In hyperv port-updates taking long time when done
sequentially and has good results using multithreaded approach.
This patch is raised so that existence of an api like this will
enable the devolopers to leverage this api if required.

Closes-Bug: #1510845

Change-Id: I134d386783a15a5c35ab4822961c35bbb92a6377
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/neutron refs/changes/89/239889/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: def update_ports_filter_bulk(self, ports): """Bulk port updates. This api is similar to update_port_filter except it takes a list of ports so that it provides an option to process all the ports simultaneously instead of one port at a time for any specific driver implementations """ raise NotImplementedError()

commit_message:
Add ml2 package requirement to neutron::plugins::ml2::mech_driver

In certain scenarios the neutron::plugins::ml2::mech_driver was being
executed before the $::neutron::params::ml2_server_package which
caused problems while trying to write plugin files.

Change-Id: I31fa00030201b86baca14f9cb3bccab91c593e85

added_lines: require => Package[$::neutron::params::ml2_server_package],

commit_message:
Use values from endpoint map for service endpoints

Instead of using values hardcoded in os-cloud-config. This commit
uses the values that come from the endpoint map that's used
in the t-h-t. This in turns, allows us to be able to change the
port and even the host used for the public and internal endpoints;
this is still not the case for the admin endpoints, as it is based
on the internal endpoint of the service. The aforementioned
limitation comes from os-cloud-config.

Change-Id: I0cf9ada1110f6b1452480039c136aee1fc3ccc82
Depends-On: I4cc5bbf2e7200f78cd90b93659c326a9200278d7
Depends-On: I07accff0914b93be09adf17a2552c5c922236c2e

added_lines: parsed_args, endpoint_map): keystone_admin_ip = endpoint_map.get('KeystoneAdmin').get('host') keystone_internal_ip = endpoint_map.get('KeystoneInternal').get('host') internal=keystone_internal_ip, public_port=endpoint_map.get('KeystonePublic').get('port'), admin_port=endpoint_map.get('KeystoneAdmin').get('port'), internal_port=endpoint_map.get('KeystoneInternal').get('port')) service_data = self._set_service_data(service, data, endpoint_map) def _set_service_data(self, service, data, endpoint_map): self.log.debug("Setting endpoint data for service '%s'" % service) service_data = data.copy() service_data.pop('password_field', None) password_field = data.get('password_field') if password_field: service_data['password'] = utils.get_password( password_field) # Set internal endpoint service_name_internal = re.sub( 'v[0-9]+', '', service.capitalize() + 'Internal') internal_endpoint_data = endpoint_map.get(service_name_internal) if not internal_endpoint_data: self.log.debug( ("Service '%s' not in endpoint map; Skipping endpoint " "data overwriting.") % service) return service_data service_data['internal_host'] = internal_endpoint_data.get('host') # Set standard port service_data['port'] = internal_endpoint_data.get('port') # Set public endpoint service_name_public = re.sub( 'v[0-9]+', '', service.capitalize() + 'Public') public_endpoint_data = endpoint_map.get(service_name_public) service_data['public_host'] = public_endpoint_data.get('host') # Set SSL port if public_endpoint_data.get('uri').startswith('https'): service_data['ssl_port'] = public_endpoint_data.get('port') return service_data endpoint_map = utils.get_endpoint_map(stack) parsed_args, endpoint_map) # Force fetching of attributes stack.get()

commit_message:
callback for AFTER_XXX event also need raise the exception

Currently, only exception raised for callback registered for BEFORE_ and
PRECOMMIT_ events, but not for AFTER_ event. It will cover some error
inside the AFTER_ callback.

For example, sync_from_callback in networking-odl will re-raise the error
from HTTP request to ODL. But the exception will not be returned back to
user which make tempest testcases passed finally.

Change-Id: Ice2141628adc2d6175c650ff8296bed8a76a6ad5
Closes-bug:#1546422
Closes-bug:#1539333
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/neutron refs/changes/18/281118/6 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

deleted_lines: raise exceptions.CallbackFailure(errors=errors) if event.startswith(events.PRECOMMIT): raise exceptions.CallbackFailure(errors=errors)

commit_message:
Add EndpointMap as output

The endpoint map contains, not only the hosts and protocols that
the resulting services will use, but also the ports. This
information is useful, and the aim of this patch is to make it
available for the tripleoclient to use it.

Change-Id: I4cc5bbf2e7200f78cd90b93659c326a9200278d7
Bug: #1569851
(cherry picked from commit 321cee7616186e83e9a5eff9e9a9abe9b9f82fab)

commit_message:
Added ensure_resource for python-memcache package.

python-memcache package is required for memcache backend
if horizon is configured to use memcache for backend.

Change-Id: I74a97ad2f220bdf88718086815f8f8db54a17f30
Closes-Bug: 1556132
(cherry picked from commit e0a67d63eba6d551f650f56c105aaf4a99efcc49)

commit_message:
Fix unless condition for ceph-deploy

In case of using an array parameter in Exec {unless}, it will run only if all
commands are false. However, we need to execute it if any of conditional
commands is false.

Change-Id: I002c734ffdbd6e6f69ff83c5f98e503e09503356
Closes-bug: #1565703
(cherry picked from commit f95c6344dce9c7caa3fe86da3a38521a2e63111c)

commit_message:
Add Unit Tests for heat_config type

Partial-bug: #1440401

Change-Id: I34a0eda08f52e5596e64ac6e7f5292f20d234683
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/puppet-heat refs/changes/81/304881/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: it 'should require a name' do expect { Puppet::Type.type(:heat_config).new({}) }.to raise_error(Puppet::Error, 'Title or name must be provided') end it 'should not expect a name with whitespace' do expect { Puppet::Type.type(:heat_config).new(:name => 'f oo') }.to raise_error(Puppet::Error, /Parameter name failed/) end it 'should fail when there is no section' do expect { Puppet::Type.type(:heat_config).new(:name => 'foo') }.to raise_error(Puppet::Error, /Parameter name failed/) end it 'should not require a value when ensure is absent' do Puppet::Type.type(:heat_config).new(:name => 'DEFAULT/foo', :ensure => :absent) end it 'should accept a valid value' do @heat_config[:value] = 'bar' expect(@heat_config[:value]).to eq('bar') end it 'should not accept a value with whitespace' do @heat_config[:value] = 'b ar' expect(@heat_config[:value]).to eq('b ar') end it 'should accept valid ensure values' do @heat_config[:ensure] = :present expect(@heat_config[:ensure]).to eq(:present) @heat_config[:ensure] = :absent expect(@heat_config[:ensure]).to eq(:absent) end it 'should not accept invalid ensure values' do expect { @heat_config[:ensure] = :latest }.to raise_error(Puppet::Error, /Invalid value/) end

[Install Guide] Fix links

Removes the broken link to the QuickStart Guide.

commit_message:
Generalize the disable-snat flag

This changes the flag to enable or disable SNAT on an external
gateway

Change-Id: I6dc9d0bad7b2a09db9810c1a624103e575bb2222

commit_message:
WIP optimize table scan for _apply_synchronized

Per comments discussion on:
https://review.openstack.org/#/c/230750/13/neutron/agent/linux/iptables_manager.py

Change-Id: Iae6c3188b20791ad90615084aa16dfe6f50584b4
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/neutron refs/changes/80/268780/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: def __lt__(self, other): return str(self) < str(other) commands = self._get_commands(args, tables) def _get_commands(self, args, tables): save_output = self.execute(args, run_as_root=True) commands = [] if not save_output: for table_name in sorted(tables.keys()): commands.append('# Generated by iptables_manager') commands.append('*' + table_name) table = tables[table_name] rule_chains = set() for rule in table.rules: if rule.wrap: rule_chains.add('%s-%s' % (rule.wrap_name, rule.chain)) else: rule_chains.add(rule.chain) our_chains = [] basic_chains = sorted(list(set(table.chains) & rule_chains)) our_chains.extend(basic_chains) our_chains.extend(sorted(table.unwrapped_chains)) wrapped_chains = sorted([ '%s-%s' % (self.wrap_name, r) for r in table.chains]) our_chains.extend(wrapped_chains) rule_chains_dict = {} our_rules = set() for rule in table.rules: if rule.wrap: current_chain = '%s-%s' % (self.wrap_name, rule.chain) else: current_chain = rule.chain if current_chain in rule_chains_dict: rule_chains_dict[current_chain] += 1 else: rule_chains_dict[current_chain] = 1 rule_number = rule_chains_dict[current_chain] rule = str(rule).split() rule.insert(2, str(rule_number)) our_rules.add(' '.join(rule).replace('-A', '-I')) rule_number += 1 commands.extend( [':%s - [0:0]' % c for c in our_chains]) commands.extend(sorted(our_rules)) commands.extend(['COMMIT', '# Completed by iptables_manager']) return commands all_lines = save_output.split('\n') # Traverse tables in sorted order for predictable dump output old_rules = [] for line in all_lines: if not line or line[0] == '#': continue if line[0] == '*': table_name = line[1:] continue if line == 'COMMIT': table = tables[table_name] # generate the new table state we want new_rules = self._modify_rules(old_rules, table, table_name) # generate the iptables commands to get between the old state # and the new state changes = _generate_path_between_rules(old_rules, new_rules) if changes: # if there are changes to the table, we put on the header # and footer that iptables-save needs commands += (['# Generated by iptables_manager'] + ['*%s' % table_name] + changes + ['COMMIT', '# Completed by iptables_manager']) old_rules = [] continue old_rules.append(line) return commands
deleted_lines: save_output = self.execute(args, run_as_root=True) all_lines = save_output.split('\n') commands = [] # Traverse tables in sorted order for predictable dump output for table_name in sorted(tables): table = tables[table_name] # isolate the lines of the table we are modifying start, end = self._find_table(all_lines, table_name) old_rules = all_lines[start:end] # generate the new table state we want new_rules = self._modify_rules(old_rules, table, table_name) # generate the iptables commands to get between the old state # and the new state changes = _generate_path_between_rules(old_rules, new_rules) if changes: # if there are changes to the table, we put on the header # and footer that iptables-save needs commands += (['# Generated by iptables_manager'] + ['*%s' % table_name] + changes + ['COMMIT', '# Completed by iptables_manager']) def _find_table(self, lines, table_name): if len(lines) < 3: # length only <2 when fake iptables return (0, 0) try: start = lines.index('*%s' % table_name) except ValueError: # Couldn't find table_name LOG.debug('Unable to find table %s', table_name) return (0, 0) end = lines[start:].index('COMMIT') + start + 1 return (start, end)

commit_message:
Python3: Add python3 support

Replaced iter.next() with next(iter)
Replaced dict.keys() + list2 with list(dict.keys()) + list2

Blueprint neutron-python3

Change-Id: I6b85ead9e68453f2784555df719607c15f5551ac

subject: DVR: avoid connection loss on floating ip associate
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-07-07 17:44:15.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/neutron/commit/7a805ded802a7fb5c16df278119ed73b35ae5dc9', 'message': 'DVR: avoid connection loss on floating ip associate

In DVR, when a floating ip is associated with a port, the current
connection to external network will be hung(and unresponsive).

The connection may be any TCP, UDP, ICMP connections which are
tracked in conntrack.

When a floating ip is associated, packets to external network are
routed through fip namespace because of ip rule[1].
Before leaving the packet, SNAT is applied [2].

But for existing connections to external network only ip rule [1]
is applied and SNAT [2] is not applied becuase of connection tracking entry [3].

So these packets enter into fip namespace and to exernal network
with local ip and will never get reply packet, hence the
connections will be in hung state.

Before assigning flaoting-ip, existing connections will be using SNAT
gateway to reach external network because of [4].

To avoid connection loss, we will continue routing these existing
connections through SNAT gateway, while associating floating ip,
by marking the packets belonging to this existing connection and
routing marked packets through fwmark routes to SNAT gateway.

1) create snat redirect route for marked packets to redirect to SNAT
default gateway(table) for the subnet before creating any floating ip
for addresses in this subnet, so that this ip rule will get higher
priority over floating ip rules. [5]

2) mark the existing conntrack connection with the same fwmark
key value used by ip rule [6]

3) restore the packet mark, from the connection, so that packet
will be handled by route with fwmark

[1] 32777:  from 10.0.0.8 lookup 16

[2] SNAT all -- * *  10.0.0.8  0.0.0.0/0  to:172.168.1.16

[3] icmp 1 29 src=10.0.0.8 dst=8.8.8.8 [UNREPLIED] src=8.8.8.8 dst=10.0.0.8 mark=0 use=1

[4] 167772161:   from 10.0.0.1/24 lookup 167772161

[5] 32769:  from 10.0.0.1/24 fwmark 0xa000001 lookup 167772161
    32777:  from 10.0.0.8 lookup 16
    167772161:      from 10.0.0.1/24 lookup 167772161

[6] icmp 1 29 src=10.0.0.8 dst=8.8.8.8 [UNREPLIED] src=8.8.8.8 dst=10.0.0.8 mark=167772161 use=1

[7] CONNMARK  all  --  *  *  10.0.0.8  0.0.0.0/0  ctorigsrc 10.0.0.8 CONNMARK restore

Closes-bug: #1456624
Change-Id: Ia668f48972a665ad8307d44fab26f7b1668b65e1
'}, {'number': 2, 'created': '2015-08-05 14:16:02.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/neutron/commit/d478fe16884c73bc9be9c9275d3d4d5327af1ee9', 'message': 'DVR: avoid connection loss on floating ip associate

In DVR, when a floating ip is associated with a port, existing
connections to external network will be hung(and unresponsive).
The connection may be any TCP, UDP, ICMP connections which are
tracked in conntrack.

Before assigning floating-ip, existing connections will be using SNAT
gateway to reach external network because of [2].

When a floating ip is associated, packets to external network are
routed through fip namespace because of ip rule[3].
This rule[3] has higher priority over [2].
And then SNAT iptables rule [4] is applied on packets.

But for existing connections to external network only ip rule [3]
is applied and SNAT [4] is not applied because of connection tracking entry [5].

So these packets enter into fip namespace and to external network
with local ip and will never get reply packet, hence the
connections will be in hung state.

To avoid connection loss on floating ip associate for existing connections,
we will continue routing packets belonging to existing connections through
SNAT gateway[2] by marking packets and routing them through new
fwmark[6] routes to SNAT gateway.

1) create snat redirect route(with fwmark)[6] for redirecting marked packets to SNAT
default gateway(table)[2]. This is route is created per router internal port(subnet).
This rule have more priority over floating ip rule [3] on that subnet.

2) Mark(using conntrack) the existing conntrack connections[7] with the same fwmark
key value used by ip rule [7]

3) Restore the packet mark(using iptables[8]), from the connection mark, so that packet
will be handled by route with fwmark

All ip rules during floating ip associate listed in [1]

[1] 32769:  from 10.0.0.1/24 fwmark 0xa000001 lookup 167772161
    32777:  from 10.0.0.8 lookup 16
    167772161:      from 10.0.0.1/24 lookup 167772161

[2] 167772161:      from 10.0.0.1/24 lookup 167772161
    ip route show table 167772161
    default via 10.0.0.7 dev qr-8804a198-ea
[3] 32777:  from 10.0.0.8 lookup 16
[4] SNAT all -- * *  10.0.0.8  0.0.0.0/0  to:172.168.1.16
[5] icmp 1 29 src=10.0.0.8 dst=8.8.8.8 [UNREPLIED] src=8.8.8.8 dst=10.0.0.8 mark=0 use=1
[6] 32769:  from 10.0.0.1/24 fwmark 0xa000001 lookup 167772161
[7] icmp 1 29 src=10.0.0.8 dst=8.8.8.8 [UNREPLIED] src=8.8.8.8 dst=10.0.0.8 mark=167772161 use=1
[8] CONNMARK  all  --  *  *  10.0.0.8  0.0.0.0/0  ctorigsrc 10.0.0.8 CONNMARK restore

Change-Id: Ia668f48972a665ad8307d44fab26f7b1668b65e1
'}, {'number': 3, 'created': '2015-08-05 14:23:50.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/neutron/commit/8f050222136851f58ad7d166f519730e4e1a38e2', 'message': 'DVR: avoid connection loss on floating ip associate

In DVR, when a floating ip is associated with a port, existing
connections to external network will be hung(and unresponsive).
The connection may be any TCP, UDP, ICMP connections which are
tracked in conntrack.

Before assigning floating-ip, existing connections will be using SNAT
gateway to reach external network because of [2].

When a floating ip is associated, packets to external network are
routed through fip namespace because of ip rule[3].
This rule[3] has higher priority over [2].
And then SNAT iptables rule [4] is applied on packets.

But for existing connections to external network only ip rule [3]
is applied and SNAT [4] is not applied because of connection tracking entry [5].

So these packets enter into fip namespace and to external network
with local ip and will never get reply packet, hence the
connections will be in hung state.

To avoid connection loss on floating ip associate for existing connections,
we will continue routing packets belonging to existing connections through
SNAT gateway[2] by marking packets and routing them through new
fwmark[6] routes to SNAT gateway.

1) create snat redirect route(with fwmark)[6] for redirecting marked packets to SNAT
default gateway(table)[2]. This is route is created per router internal port(subnet).
This rule have more priority over floating ip rule [3] on that subnet.

2) Mark(using conntrack) the existing conntrack connections[7] with the same fwmark
key value used by ip rule [7]

3) Restore the packet mark(using iptables[8]), from the connection mark, so that packet
will be handled by route with fwmark

All ip rules during floating ip associate listed in [1]

[1] 32769:  from 10.0.0.1/24 fwmark 0xa000001 lookup 167772161
    32777:  from 10.0.0.8 lookup 16
    167772161:      from 10.0.0.1/24 lookup 167772161

[2] 167772161:      from 10.0.0.1/24 lookup 167772161
    ip route show table 167772161
    default via 10.0.0.7 dev qr-8804a198-ea
[3] 32777:  from 10.0.0.8 lookup 16
[4] SNAT all -- * *  10.0.0.8  0.0.0.0/0  to:172.168.1.16
[5] icmp 1 29 src=10.0.0.8 dst=8.8.8.8 [UNREPLIED] src=8.8.8.8 dst=10.0.0.8 mark=0 use=1
[6] 32769:  from 10.0.0.1/24 fwmark 0xa000001 lookup 167772161
[7] icmp 1 29 src=10.0.0.8 dst=8.8.8.8 [UNREPLIED] src=8.8.8.8 dst=10.0.0.8 mark=167772161 use=1
[8] CONNMARK  all  --  *  *  10.0.0.8  0.0.0.0/0  ctorigsrc 10.0.0.8 CONNMARK restore

Closes-bug: #1456624
Change-Id: Ia668f48972a665ad8307d44fab26f7b1668b65e1

commit_message:
DVR: avoid connection loss on floating ip associate

Problem is explained in bug report
https://bugs.launchpad.net/neutron/+bug/1456624/comments/7

To avoid connection loss on floating ip associate for existing connections,
we will continue routing packets belonging to existing connections through
SNAT gateway[2] by marking packets and routing them through new
fwmark[6] routes to SNAT gateway.

1) create snat redirect route(with fwmark)[6] for redirecting marked packets to SNAT
default gateway(table)[2]. This is route is created per router internal port(subnet).
This rule have more priority over floating ip rule [3] on that subnet.

2) Mark(using conntrack) the existing conntrack connections[7] with the same fwmark
key value used by ip rule [7]

3) Restore the packet mark(using iptables[8]), from the connection mark, so that packet
will be handled by route with fwmark

All ip rules(including new fwmark rule) in compute node will look like [1] with this change.

[1] 32769:  from 10.0.0.1/24 fwmark 0xa000001 lookup 167772161
    32777:  from 10.0.0.8 lookup 16
    167772161:      from 10.0.0.1/24 lookup 167772161

[2] 167772161:      from 10.0.0.1/24 lookup 167772161
    ip route show table 167772161
    default via 10.0.0.7 dev qr-8804a198-ea
[3] 32777:  from 10.0.0.8 lookup 16
[6] 32769:  from 10.0.0.1/24 fwmark 0xa000001 lookup 167772161
[7] icmp 1 29 src=10.0.0.8 dst=8.8.8.8 [UNREPLIED] src=8.8.8.8 dst=10.0.0.8 mark=167772161 use=1
[8] CONNMARK  all  --  *  *  10.0.0.8  0.0.0.0/0  ctorigsrc 10.0.0.8 CONNMARK restore

Closes-bug: #1456624
Change-Id: Ia668f48972a665ad8307d44fab26f7b1668b65e1
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/neutron refs/changes/96/199196/8 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: def _get_internal_gw_cidr_for_ip_adress(self, ip_address): """Return router's internal gateway cidr based on ip_address.""" router_ports = self.router.get(l3_constants.INTERFACE_KEY, []) for port in router_ports: fips = port['fixed_ips'] for f in fips: subnet_ports = self.agent.get_ports_by_subnet(f['subnet_id']) for p in subnet_ports: for fixed_ip in p['fixed_ips']: if fixed_ip['ip_address'] == ip_address: return common_utils.ip_to_cidr(f['ip_address'], f['prefixlen']) def mark_exising_connections(self, fixed_ip, floating_ip): """Mark existing connections with this fixed_ip for SNAT.""" # use snat_idx as mark value, ip rule exists with this mark value # as a routing key to redirect traffic to SNAT gateway sn_port_cidr = self._get_internal_gw_cidr_for_ip_adress(fixed_ip) snat_idx = self._get_snat_idx(sn_port_cidr) ip_wrapr = ip_lib.IPWrapper(namespace=self.ns_name) # we can't use iptable rule with CONNMARK target for marking the # connection as this rule might hit by existing and new connections ip_wrapr.netns.execute(['conntrack', '-U', 'conntrack', '-s', fixed_ip, '--mark', snat_idx]) # mark packets from connection mark. Packets with this mark will be # routed through SNAT gateway because of ip rule with fwmark rule = ('-s %s -m conntrack --ctorigsrc %s -j CONNMARK --restore-mark' % (fixed_ip, fixed_ip)) # tag the restore rule with floating-ip, so that this rule can be # deleted while disassociating floating-ip tag = '%s' % (floating_ip) self.iptables_manager.ipv4['mangle'].add_rule('PREROUTING', rule, tag=tag) self.iptables_manager.apply() # mark existing SNAT connections to avoid connection loss self.mark_exising_connections(fixed_ip, floating_ip) # clear packet marking rule tag = '%s' % (floating_ip) self.iptables_manager.ipv4['mangle'].clear_rules_by_tag(tag) self.iptables_manager.apply() # remove SNAT redirect marking routes for p in self.internal_ports: self._snat_redirect_for_connections(p, False) def update_fwmark_ip_rule(self, sn_port_cidr, port_ip_vers, snat_idx, is_add): """ Add or delete ip rule to handle marked packets """ ns_ipr = ip_lib.IPRule(namespace=self.ns_name) # add rule if route to SNAT gateway exists if is_add and ns_ipr.rule._exists(port_ip_vers, ip=sn_port_cidr, table=snat_idx, priority=snat_idx): rule_pr = self.fip_ns.allocate_rule_priority() # Add rule only if it doesn't exist if not ns_ipr.rule._exists(port_ip_vers, ip=sn_port_cidr, table=snat_idx, fwmark=snat_idx): ns_ipr.rule.add(sn_port_cidr, table=snat_idx, priority=rule_pr, fwmark=snat_idx) # delete rule only if it exists elif ns_ipr.rule._exists(port_ip_vers, ip=sn_port_cidr, table=snat_idx, fwmark=snat_idx): ns_ipr.rule.delete(sn_port_cidr, table=snat_idx, fwmark=snat_idx) def _snat_redirect_for_connections(self, sn_port, is_add): """manage routes to handle marked packets to avoid connection loss for existing SNAT connections. """ for port_fixed_ip in sn_port['fixed_ips']: port_ip_addr = port_fixed_ip['ip_address'] sn_port_cidr = common_utils.ip_to_cidr(port_ip_addr, port_fixed_ip['prefixlen']) # Derive snat_idx from subnet gateway address. # Same key can be calculated and marked for conntrack connections # with source ip from this subnet snat_idx = self._get_snat_idx(sn_port_cidr) port_ip_vers = netaddr.IPAddress(port_ip_addr).version self.update_fwmark_ip_rule(sn_port_cidr, port_ip_vers, snat_idx, is_add) if self.fip_ns: self.update_fwmark_ip_rule(sn_port_cidr, port_ip_vers, snat_idx, is_add) # create SNAT redirect route for each subnet # to avoid connection loss for existing SNAT connections for p in self.internal_ports: self._snat_redirect_for_connections(p, True)

commit_message:
WIP: Use compare-and-swap for IpamAvailabilityRange

WIP: Enabled pluggable IPAM

Existing locking mechanism 'select for update' causes
deadlocks with galera multi-writers.
Replaced locking rows with compare-and-swap approach.

Compare-and-swap verifies that row is not changed by
another thread before updating/deleting it.
Filter-and-update and filter-and-delete are used.
They return count of affected rows.
If count of affected row is less than expected,
then another thread already changed our row
and RetryRequest is raised.

Change-Id: I514cae0fa43033433ec2982bcf3726e02e6692bf
Closes-Bug: #1494351
(cherry picked from commit d755f7248d324bb4c44b3efc9d200f8eb075066d)

subject: Extend the str2dict to support the dict list in cmdline
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-07-16 12:48:19.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/python-neutronclient/commit/89a441d4cf8ea866d1e4548a18c26202f047bfab', 'message': 'Extend the way to update the fixed-ips by cmdline

Currently when update fixed-ips, {subnet_id=xx,ip_address=xx} will be translated
to two requirement respectively, will generate two ip for one subnet.
But actually user just want to add one IP with the specified subnet_id.
This patch extend the str2dict function to process the string like below. It use
';' to divide the string wrapped with "". Then it will get a list of dict.

--fixed-ips type=dict  "{subnet_id=xx,ip_address=xx};{subnet_id=xx}"

commit_message:
Extend the str2dict to support the dict list in cmdline

Currently when update fixed-ips, {subnet_id=xx,ip_address=xx} will be translated
to two requirement respectively, will generate two ip for one subnet.
But actually user just want to add one IP with the specified subnet_id.
This patch extend the str2dict function to process the string like below. It use
';' to divide the string wrapped with "". Then it will get a list of dict.

--fixed-ips type=dict  "{subnet_id=xx,ip_address=xx};{subnet_id=xx}"

Change-Id: I03b302f0a1c60bfe4da1d6c18eadb9939ab46940
Partial-Bug: #1341096

subject: Deny extra arguments for router gateway and interface CLIs
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-01-19 10:40:32.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/python-neutronclient/commit/49836f7de304f04cdc8b5a124a376d6bcb8d32d5', 'message': "Send extra attributes in body

In classes that implements it's own run() method, it didn't add extra
attributes in body, so they are not sent to neutron server. This lead to
a problem that if you type a wrong attribute, it is silently striped,
and no error will occor.
This patch added the extra attributes in request body, so that neutron
server will raise an error if the attributes are wrong.

Change-Id: I68cb9b03c211eece32ab77dea866fd8f98dfab63
Closes-Bug: #1535209

commit_message:
Deny extra arguments for router gateway and interface CLIs

For router-gateway-set/clear, router-interface-add/delete commands,
if user passed some wrong arguments, no error will shown.
This patch deny extra arguments for these commands and display an error message.

Change-Id: I68cb9b03c211eece32ab77dea866fd8f98dfab63
Closes-Bug: #1535209

added_lines: monitoring the Devstack VM. It will then be possible to configure a Nagios datasource for Vitrage. The following guide is for Ubuntu. With slight modifications it should work for2. Update your repo with the OMD site. For example, for ubuntu wheezy release:4. Create a site for nagios with a name of your choosing, for example "my_site". sudo omd create my_site sudo omd config my_site set APACHE_TCP_PORT 54321 sudo omd config my_site set APACHE_TCP_ADDR 0.0.0.0 sudo omd start my_site You can now access your Nagios site here: *http://<devstack_ip>:54321/my_site/omd*. - *APACHE_TCP_ADDR* indicates the address to listen on. Use 0.0.0.0 to listen for all traffic addressed to the specified port. Use a different address to listen on a specific (public) address. 5. Install the Check_MK agent on devstack VM:6. Activate the Check_MK agent, by editing */etc/xinetd.d/check_mk* and **setting "disable" to "no"**, and then run7. In your browser, go to *http://<devstack_ip>:<selected port>/my_site/omd* and follow the instructions at this link_ (**"Configuring the first host and checks"** section) to configure the nagios host.8. *Vitrage Support.* With Nagios installed, you can now configure a datasource for it for Vitrage, by following the instructions here_. .. _here: https://github.com/openstack/vitrage/blob/master/doc/source/nagios-config.rst

commit_message:
Add --router:external to net-create arguments

router:external is not in CreateNetwork known_arguments. This allows
help message of router:external to output when creating a network through
cli.

Change-Id: I644ca6f4797b7c7564e0d62da44126957177de78
Closes-Bug: #1552721

commit_message:
OVS-agent: Deprecate drop_flows_on_start

This option has no clear use-cases for end users.
Let's remove it after a cycle.  At that point the new behaviour
(graceful restart) should have been proved stable.

Change-Id: I196e012b5a37594bf8eeb497ccea41afb822cfd1

commit_message:
Set VXLAN UDP destination port using Linux Bridge

Fix Cannot set the VXLAN UDP destination port to 4789 using Linux Bridge

DocImpact: Add option of the VXLAN UDP destination port with Linux Bridge,
set default to 8472 to not break existing installations that haven't specified
vxlan_udp_port so far.

Change-Id: If8175ed2cb2a74d31b8c65e19c3b2832ac8adc4d
Closes-Bug: #1483853

commit_message:
Fix floatingip status for an HA router

When we associate a floatingip in an HA router setup, it is properly
associated. However, when we check the status of the Floating ip, it
is shown as empty.  The L3 agent ha_router implementation never sets
the status of the floating IP when it's added.  This behavior blocks
tempest scenario tests that use FIPs when run against a deployment
with L3 agent HA routers.  This fix sets the FIP status to active
when the FIP is added by an HaRouter instance.

Conflicts:
	neutron/tests/functional/agent/l3/framework.py
	neutron/tests/functional/agent/l3/test_dvr_router.py
	neutron/tests/functional/agent/l3/test_ha_router.py
	neutron/tests/functional/agent/l3/test_legacy_router.py

Co-Authored-By: Assaf Muller <amuller@redhat.com>
Closes-Bug: #1449049
Change-Id: I7a3de36b64132e483a927ce9fed30777e84df96a
(cherry picked from commit 30e048d222c23c8fa07f70fa2d6a820fa0c88e0c)
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/neutron refs/changes/42/271742/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: def _test_update_floatingip_statuses(self, router_info): router = self.manage_router(self.agent, router_info) rpc = self.agent.plugin_rpc.update_floatingip_statuses self.assertTrue(rpc.called) # Assert that every defined FIP is updated via RPC expected_fips = set([ (fip['id'], l3_constants.FLOATINGIP_STATUS_ACTIVE) for fip in router.router[l3_constants.FLOATINGIP_KEY]]) call = [args[0] for args in rpc.call_args_list][0] actual_fips = set( [(fip_id, status) for fip_id, status in call[2].items()]) self.assertEqual(expected_fips, actual_fips) def test_legacy_router_update_floatingip_statuses(self): self._test_update_floatingip_statuses( self.generate_router_info(enable_ha=False)) def test_ha_router_update_floatingip_statuses(self): self._test_update_floatingip_statuses( self.generate_router_info(enable_ha=True)) def test_dvr_update_floatingip_statuses(self): self.agent.conf.agent_mode = 'dvr' self._test_update_floatingip_statuses(self.generate_dvr_router_info())

subject: Disabling/Re-enabling ML2 type driver create orphan n/w segments
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-11-13 13:18:11.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/neutron/commit/163345d415c9f19f7d68a7aabffaf04c0a582a5a', 'message': 'Disabling/Re-enabling ML2 type driver creates orphaned n/w segments.

Currently a warning is documented for ML2 type driver configuration
saying "Disabling a ML2 type driver and re-enabling it later may
lead to database inconsistencies if ML2 is reconfigured without
support for that type.". But there hasn't been any clear consensus
on what will be the correct fix for this. Some solutions have been
proposed that fixes the problem in a SQL query/script fix.

In this proposed solution, there are no foreign key based database
triggers/database scripts for the admin. Currently the segments are
released by the type driver loaded specific to that type. So this
change intends to use the type driver to release the segment.
When the plugin creates & initializes the type driver it passes in
all the existing networks using the admin context. The type manager
registers all the unique network segment types from that list. It
then takes the types from this list which are not there configured
in "type_drivers" in [ml2] group inside ml2_conf.ini. Type manager
loads these orphaned type drivers and keeps a separate list which
will not be used for any segment manipulations other than during
release. While releasing the segments if it cannot find a driver
to unload the segment, it searches this orphaned driver list. It
tries to release the segment using the orphaned driver. This way
there will be no database inconsistencies and the same segmentation
ID could be used when the type is re-enabled later. As the types
are tuned, n/ws are deleted, and service gets restarted the
orphaned driver list eventually becomes empty.

DocImpact

Change-Id: If08b304a9388058003d9f86f58295c6b5daef846
Closes-Bug: 1311470

'}, {'number': 9, 'created': '2015-12-04 11:31:49.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/neutron/commit/a3362f3398277359dcc8afae25f054573674c25f', 'message': 'Disabling/Re-enabling ML2 type driver create orphan n/w segments

Currently a warning is documented for ML2 type driver configuration
saying "Disabling a ML2 type driver and re-enabling it later may
lead to database inconsistencies if ML2 is reconfigured without
support for that type.". But there hasn't been any clear consensus
on what will be the correct fix for this. Some solutions have been
proposed that fixes the problem in a SQL query/script fix.

In this proposed solution, there are no foreign key based database
triggers/database scripts for the admin. Currently the segments are
released by the type driver loaded specific to that type. So this
change intends to use the type driver to release the segment.
When the plugin releases the network segments it passes all the
segments to a orphan type discovery function in type manager. It
registers all the unique network segment types from that list. It
then takes the types from this list which are not there configured
in "type_drivers" in [ml2] group inside ml2_conf.ini. Type manager
loads type drivers from "orphan_type_drivers" in [ml2] group inside
ml2_conf.ini. From this list it then registers the orphaned segment
type driver for the orphaned types already discovered. These drivers
will be kept separate and will not be used for any segment
manipulations other than during release. While releasing the segment
if it cannot find a driver to unload the segment, it searches the
orphaned driver list. It tries to release the segment using the
orphaned driver. This way there will be no database inconsistencies
and the same segmentation ID could be used when the type is
re-enabled later. As the types are tuned, n/ws are deleted, and
service gets restarted the registered orphaned driver list
eventually will become empty.

DocImpact: Add the new configuration variable 'orphan_type_drivers'
and its description to the docs.
In http://docs.ocselected.org/openstack-manuals/kilo/
networking-guide/content/ml2_scenarios.html there is a Warning
message 'Disabling a ML2 type driver and re-enabling it later may
lead to database inconsistencies...'. To that add
'To avoid inconsistencies and orphaned network segments, add the
removed driver name or the driver to be used to release the network
segment to neutron.ml2.orphan_type_drivers. For more details see
help for orphan_type_drivers'

Change-Id: If08b304a9388058003d9f86f58295c6b5daef846
Closes-Bug: 1311470
'}, {'number': 10, 'created': '2015-12-07 06:50:54.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/neutron/commit/c4dae76326fb034d1ddc7c75eb23d892fb4da7b4', 'message': 'Disabling/Re-enabling ML2 type driver create orphan n/w segments

Currently a warning is documented for ML2 type driver configuration
saying "Disabling a ML2 type driver and re-enabling it later may
lead to database inconsistencies if ML2 is reconfigured without
support for that type.". But there hasn't been any clear consensus
on what will be the correct fix for this. Some solutions have been
proposed that fixes the problem in a SQL query/script fix.

In this proposed solution, there are no foreign key based database
triggers/database scripts for the admin. Currently the segments are
released by the type driver loaded specific to that type. So this
change intends to use the type driver to release the segment.
When the plugin releases the network segments it passes all the
segments to an orphan type discovery function in type manager. It
registers all the unique network segment types from that list. It
then takes the types from this list which are not there configured
in "type_drivers" in [ml2] group inside ml2_conf.ini. Type manager
loads type drivers from "disabled_type_drivers" in [ml2] group inside
ml2_conf.ini. From this list it then registers the orphaned segment
type driver for the orphaned types already discovered. These drivers
will be kept separate and will not be used for any segment
manipulations other than during release. While releasing the segment
if it cannot find a driver to unload the segment, it searches the
disabled driver list. It tries to release the segment using a driver
from this list. This way there will be no database inconsistencies
and the same segmentation ID could be re-used when the type is
re-enabled later. As the types are tuned, n/ws are deleted, and
service gets restarted the registered orphaned driver list in
type manager eventually will become empty.

DocImpact: Add the new configuration variable 'disabled_type_drivers'
and its description to the docs.
In 'http://docs.ocselected.org/openstack-manuals/kilo/\
networking-guide/content/ml2_scenarios.html' there is a Warning
message 'Disabling a ML2 type driver and re-enabling it later may
lead to database inconsistencies...'. To that add
'To avoid inconsistencies and non-reusable network segments, add the
removed driver name or the driver to be used to properly delete the
network segment to 'neutron.ml2.disabled_type_drivers'.
For more details see help for 'disabled_type_drivers'.

Change-Id: If08b304a9388058003d9f86f58295c6b5daef846
Closes-Bug: 1311470

service gets restarted the registered orphaned driver list in
type manager eventually will become empty.

DocImpact: Add the new configuration variable 'disabled_type_drivers'
and its description to the docs.
In 'http://docs.ocselected.org/openstack-manuals/kilo/\
networking-guide/content/ml2_scenarios.html' there is a Warning
message 'Disabling a ML2 type driver and re-enabling it later may
lead to database inconsistencies...'. To that add
'To avoid inconsistencies and non-reusable network segments, add the
removed driver name or the driver to be used to properly delete the
network segment to 'neutron.ml2.disabled_type_drivers'.
For more details see help for 'disabled_type_drivers'.

Change-Id: If08b304a9388058003d9f86f58295c6b5daef846
Closes-Bug: 1311470
'}, {'number': 12, 'created': '2015-12-08 07:44:31.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/neutron/commit/352fe23374dff98b60a6b69b291e8bc9f7c3cd08', 'message': 'Disabling/Re-enabling ML2 type driver create orphan n/w segments

Currently a warning is documented for ML2 type driver configuration
saying "Disabling a ML2 type driver and re-enabling it later may
lead to database inconsistencies if ML2 is reconfigured without
support for that type.". But there hasn't been any clear consensus
on what will be the correct fix for this. Some solutions have been
proposed that fixes the problem in a SQL query/script fix.

In this proposed solution, there are no foreign key based database
triggers/database scripts for the admin. Currently the segments are
released by the type driver loaded specific to that type. So this
change intends to use the type driver to release the segment.
When the plugin releases the network segments it passes all the
segments to an orphan type discovery function in type manager. It
registers all the unique network segment types from that list. It
then takes the types from this list which are not there configured
in "type_drivers" in [ml2] group inside ml2_conf.ini. Type manager
loads type drivers from "disabled_type_drivers" in [ml2] group inside
ml2_conf.ini. From this list it then registers the orphaned segment
type driver for the orphaned types already discovered. These drivers
will be kept separate and will not be used for any segment
manipulations other than during release. While releasing the segment
if it cannot find a driver to unload the segment, it searches the
disabled driver list. It tries to release the segment using a driver
from this list. This way there will be no database inconsistencies
and the same segmentation ID could be re-used when the type is
re-enabled later. As the types are tuned, n/ws are deleted, and
service gets restarted the registered orphaned driver list in
type manager eventually will become empty.

DocImpact: Add the new configuration variable 'disabled_type_drivers'
and its description to the docs.
In 'http://docs.ocselected.org/openstack-manuals/kilo/\
networking-guide/content/ml2_scenarios.html' there is a Warning

network segment to 'neutron.ml2.disabled_type_drivers'.

commit_message:
Disabling/Re-enabling ML2 type driver create orphan n/w segments

Currently a warning is documented for ML2 type driver configuration
saying "Disabling a ML2 type driver and re-enabling it later may
lead to database inconsistencies if ML2 is reconfigured without
support for that type.". But there hasn't been any clear consensus
on what will be the correct fix for this. Some solutions have been
proposed that fixes the problem in a SQL query/script fix.

In this proposed solution, there are no foreign key based database
triggers/database scripts for the admin. Currently the segments are
released by the type driver loaded specific to that type. So this
change intends to use the type driver to release the segment.
Type manager loads all type drivers from the namespace. From this
list it then registers the enabled and disabled drivers using the
"type_drivers" config option. These disabled drivers will be kept
separate and will not be used for any segment manipulations other
than during release. While releasing the segment if it cannot find
a driver to unload the segment, it searches the disabled driver
list. It tries to release the segment using a driver from this
list. This way there will be no database inconsistencies and the
same segmentation ID could be re-used when the type is re-enabled
later.

DocImpact: In 'http://docs.ocselected.org/openstack-manuals/kilo/\
networking-guide/content/ml2_scenarios.html' there is a Warning
message 'Disabling a ML2 type driver and re-enabling it later may
lead to database inconsistencies...'. Remove this warning from the
docs as the service now can properly delete the segments.

Change-Id: If08b304a9388058003d9f86f58295c6b5daef846
Closes-Bug: 1311470

commit_message:
[WIP] Restore ebtables_driver/manager

The linuxbridge-dvr feature uses ebtables to manage DVR packet.
This patch reverts the patch[1].

[1]: https://review.openstack.org/#/c/221364/

Change-Id: Iabced6ee64b7203ef21ceb8519bd6fa53acba565
Related-Bug: #1504039
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/neutron refs/changes/06/266106/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # Copyright (c) 2015 OpenStack Foundation. # All Rights Reserved. # # Licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the "License"); you may # not use this file except in compliance with the License. You may obtain # a copy of the License at # # http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0 # # Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software # distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS, WITHOUT # WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or implied. See the # License for the specific language governing permissions and limitations # under the License. # """Implement ebtables rules using linux utilities.""" import re from retrying import retry from oslo_config import cfg from oslo_log import log as logging from neutron.common import utils ebtables_opts = [ cfg.StrOpt('ebtables_path', default='$state_path/ebtables-', help=_('Location of temporary ebtables table files.')), ] CONF = cfg.CONF CONF.register_opts(ebtables_opts) LOG = logging.getLogger(__name__) # Collection of regexes to parse ebtables output _RE_FIND_BRIDGE_TABLE_NAME = re.compile(r'^Bridge table:[\s]*([a-z]+)$') # get chain name, nunmber of entries and policy name. _RE_FIND_BRIDGE_CHAIN_INFO = re.compile( r'^Bridge chain:[\s]*(.*),[\s]*entries:[\s]*[0-9]+,[\s]*' r'policy:[\s]*([A-Z]+)$') _RE_FIND_BRIDGE_RULE_COUNTERS = re.compile( r',[\s]*pcnt[\s]*=[\s]*([0-9]+)[\s]*--[\s]*bcnt[\s]*=[\s]*([0-9]+)$') _RE_FIND_COMMIT_STATEMENT = re.compile(r'^COMMIT$') _RE_FIND_COMMENTS_AND_BLANKS = re.compile(r'^#|^$') _RE_FIND_APPEND_RULE = re.compile(r'-A (\S+) ') # Regexes to parse ebtables rule file input _RE_RULES_FIND_TABLE_NAME = re.compile(r'^\*([a-z]+)$') _RE_RULES_FIND_CHAIN_NAME = re.compile(r'^:(.*)[\s]+([A-Z]+)$') _RE_RULES_FIND_RULE_LINE = re.compile(r'^\[([0-9]+):([0-9]+)\]') def _process_ebtables_output(lines): """Process raw output of ebtables rule listing file. Empty lines and comments removed, ebtables listing output converted into ebtables rules. For example, if the raw ebtables list lines (input to this function) are: Bridge table: filter Bridge chain: INPUT, entries: 0, policy: ACCEPT Bridge chain: FORWARD, entries: 0, policy: ACCEPT Bridge chain: OUTPUT, entries: 0, policy: ACCEPT The output then will be: *filter :INPUT ACCEPT :FORWARD ACCEPT :OUTPUT ACCEPT COMMIT Key point: ebtables rules listing output is not the same as the rules format for setting new rules. """ table = None chain = '' chains = [] rules = [] for line in lines: if _RE_FIND_COMMENTS_AND_BLANKS.search(line): continue match = _RE_FIND_BRIDGE_RULE_COUNTERS.search(line) if table and match: rules.append('[%s:%s] -A %s %s' % (match.group(1), match.group(2), chain, line[:match.start()].strip())) match = _RE_FIND_BRIDGE_CHAIN_INFO.search(line) if match: chains.append(':%s %s' % (match.group(1), match.group(2))) chain = match.group(1) continue match = _RE_FIND_BRIDGE_TABLE_NAME.search(line) if match: table = '*%s' % match.group(1) continue return [table] + chains + rules + ['COMMIT'] def _match_rule_line(table, line): match = _RE_RULES_FIND_RULE_LINE.search(line) if table and match: args = line[match.end():].split() res = [(table, args)] if int(match.group(1)) > 0 and int(match.group(2)) > 0: p = _RE_FIND_APPEND_RULE rule = p.sub(r'-C \1 %s %s ', line[match.end() + 1:]) args = (rule % (match.group(1), match.group(2))).split() res.append((table, args)) return table, res else: return table, None def _match_chain_name(table, tables, line): match = _RE_RULES_FIND_CHAIN_NAME.search(line) if table and match: if match.group(1) not in tables[table]: args = ['-N', match.group(1), '-P', match.group(2)] else: args = ['-P', match.group(1), match.group(2)] return table, (table, args) else: return table, None def _match_table_name(table, line): match = _RE_RULES_FIND_TABLE_NAME.search(line) if match: # Initialize with current kernel table if we just start out table = match.group(1) return table, (table, ['--atomic-init']) else: return table, None def _match_commit_statement(table, line): match = _RE_FIND_COMMIT_STATEMENT.search(line) if table and match: # Conclude by issuing the commit command return (table, ['--atomic-commit']) else: return None def _process_ebtables_input(lines): """Import text ebtables rules. Similar to iptables-restore. Was based on: http://sourceforge.net/p/ebtables/code/ci/ 3730ceb7c0a81781679321bfbf9eaa39cfcfb04e/tree/userspace/ebtables2/ ebtables-save?format=raw The function prepares and returns a list of tuples, each tuple consisting of a table name and ebtables arguments. The caller can then repeatedly call ebtables on that table with those arguments to get the rules applied. For example, this input: *filter :INPUT ACCEPT :FORWARD ACCEPT :OUTPUT ACCEPT :neutron-nwfilter-spoofing-fallb ACCEPT :neutron-nwfilter-OUTPUT ACCEPT :neutron-nwfilter-INPUT ACCEPT :neutron-nwfilter-FORWARD ACCEPT [0:0] -A INPUT -j neutron-nwfilter-INPUT [0:0] -A OUTPUT -j neutron-nwfilter-OUTPUT [0:0] -A FORWARD -j neutron-nwfilter-FORWARD [0:0] -A neutron-nwfilter-spoofing-fallb -j DROP COMMIT ... produces this output: ('filter', ['--atomic-init']) ('filter', ['-P', 'INPUT', 'ACCEPT']) ('filter', ['-P', 'FORWARD', 'ACCEPT']) ('filter', ['-P', 'OUTPUT', 'ACCEPT']) ('filter', ['-N', 'neutron-nwfilter-spoofing-fallb', '-P', 'ACCEPT']) ('filter', ['-N', 'neutron-nwfilter-OUTPUT', '-P', 'ACCEPT']) ('filter', ['-N', 'neutron-nwfilter-INPUT', '-P', 'ACCEPT']) ('filter', ['-N', 'neutron-nwfilter-FORWARD', '-P', 'ACCEPT']) ('filter', ['-A', 'INPUT', '-j', 'neutron-nwfilter-INPUT']) ('filter', ['-A', 'OUTPUT', '-j', 'neutron-nwfilter-OUTPUT']) ('filter', ['-A', 'FORWARD', '-j', 'neutron-nwfilter-FORWARD']) ('filter', ['-A', 'neutron-nwfilter-spoofing-fallb', '-j', 'DROP']) ('filter', ['--atomic-commit']) """ tables = {'filter': ['INPUT', 'FORWARD', 'OUTPUT'], 'nat': ['PREROUTING', 'OUTPUT', 'POSTROUTING'], 'broute': ['BROUTING']} table = None ebtables_args = list() for line in lines.splitlines(): if _RE_FIND_COMMENTS_AND_BLANKS.search(line): continue table, res = _match_rule_line(table, line) if res: ebtables_args.extend(res) continue table, res = _match_chain_name(table, tables, line) if res: ebtables_args.append(res) continue table, res = _match_table_name(table, line) if res: ebtables_args.append(res) continue res = _match_commit_statement(table, line) if res: ebtables_args.append(res) continue return ebtables_args @retry(wait_exponential_multiplier=1000, wait_exponential_max=10000, stop_max_delay=10000) def _cmd_retry(func, *args, **kwargs): return func(*args, **kwargs) def run_ebtables(namespace, execute, table, args): """Run ebtables utility, with retry if necessary. Provide table name and list of additional arguments to ebtables. """ cmd = ['ebtables', '-t', table] if CONF.ebtables_path: f = '%s%s' % (CONF.ebtables_path, table) cmd += ['--atomic-file', f] cmd += args if namespace: cmd = ['ip', 'netns', 'exec', namespace] + cmd # TODO(jbrendel): The root helper is used for every ebtables command, # but as we use an atomic file we only need root for # init and commit commands. # But the generated file by init ebtables command is # only readable and writable by root. # # We retry the execution of ebtables in case of failure. Known issue: # See bug: https://bugs.launchpad.net/nova/+bug/1316621 # See patch: https://review.openstack.org/#/c/140514/3 return _cmd_retry(execute, cmd, **{"run_as_root": True}) def run_ebtables_multiple(namespace, execute, arg_list): """Run ebtables utility multiple times. Similar to run(), but runs ebtables for every element in arg_list. Each arg_list element is a tuple containing the table name and a list of ebtables arguments. """ for table, args in arg_list: run_ebtables(namespace, execute, table, args) @utils.synchronized('ebtables', external=True) def ebtables_save(execute, tables_names, namespace=None): """Generate text output of the ebtables rules. Based on: http://sourceforge.net/p/ebtables/code/ci/master/tree/userspace/ebtables2/ ebtables-save?format=raw """ raw_outputs = (run_ebtables(namespace, execute, t, ['-L', '--Lc']).splitlines() for t in tables_names) parsed_outputs = (_process_ebtables_output(lines) for lines in raw_outputs) return '\n'.join(l for lines in parsed_outputs for l in lines) @utils.synchronized('ebtables', external=True) def ebtables_restore(lines, execute, namespace=None): """Import text ebtables rules and apply.""" ebtables_args = _process_ebtables_input(lines) run_ebtables_multiple(namespace, execute, ebtables_args)

commit_message:
Allow network owner get and delete all subnets

Current policy allow "admin_or_network_owner" to create subnet,
but only allow "admin_or_owner" to get network. This will stop
network owner to get a subnet created by admin.

This stops network owner to have total control to its network.
Such as, network owner cannot create port on its network,
cannot add this subnet onto a router as interface. And stops
network owner to delete its networks(when some subnets on its
network not owner by it) and those subnets not owned by it, even
policy allows:
  "delete_subnet": "rule:admin_or_network_owner"
  "delete_network": "rule:admin_or_owner"

Attention, this shouldn't be considered as a RBAC related issue.

This patch will fix this.

Closes-Bug: #1536176
Change-Id: I6a66bc039d86a844ab20294001a14bb69c166fea
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/neutron refs/changes/83/270183/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
messy info returned when an operation is not allowed by policy

Instead of simple message like "disallowed by policy", messy info
is returned when an operation is not allowed by the policy.

Change-Id: Ic0c21353221fb5e07f58a69e962cdefe5ea9994c
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/neutron refs/changes/39/265739/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: if isinstance(e, oslo_policy.PolicyNotAuthorized): if hasattr(e, 'args'): e.args = (_('Disallowed by policy'),)

subject: Don't register HA router to L3 agent when ha_port is not found
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-10-31 13:18:54.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/neutron/commit/0a41725dea7b9f57c9ee5bf44358fcc270d12f71', 'message': "Don't register HA router to L3 agent when ha_port is not found

From the server side, router has a chance to be deleted during
the sync from L3 agent. If the deletion just happens before
[1], HA router that the L3 agent wants to sync will not include
HA_INTERFACE_KEY.
From the L3 agent side, if it is the first time that L3 agent
sync this HA router, there is a chance that the router is
registered to L3 agent's router_info before removal. Without
HA_INTERFACE_KEY, code will hit [2], and will register an in-
complete router into L3 agent's router_info. This makes following
action(removal) unable to finish, and will cause fullsync of
routers all the time.

The fix can be 2 directions, either one will work:
From the L3RouterPlugin, get HA_INTERFACE_KEY for HA router first.
Then get other router information and return to L3 agent. This
patch don't contain such change because it is a very rare case
and I am not sure if it will break other things.

From the L3NATAgent, don't register HA router to L3 agent when
ha_port is not found, and raise an exception to let [3] handle it.
As a result, L3 agent don't have to hanle the upcoming remove rpc
message with the in-complete router into, according to [4].

commit_message:
Don't register HA router to L3 agent when ha_port is not found

From the server side, router has a chance to be deleted during
the sync from L3 agent. If the deletion just happens before
[1], HA router that the L3 agent wants to sync will not include
HA_INTERFACE_KEY.
From the L3 agent side, if it is the first time that L3 agent
sync this HA router, there is a chance that the router is
registered to L3 agent's router_info before removal. Without
HA_INTERFACE_KEY, code will hit [2], and will register an in-
complete router into L3 agent's router_info. This makes following
action(removal) unable to finish, and will cause fullsync of
routers all the time.

The fix can be 2 directions, either one will work:
From the L3RouterPlugin, get HA_INTERFACE_KEY for HA router first.
Then get other router information and return to L3 agent. This
patch don't contain such change because it is a very rare case
and I am not sure if it will break other things.

From the L3NATAgent, don't register HA router to L3 agent when
ha_port is not found, and raise an exception to let [3] handle it.
As a result, L3 agent don't have to hanle the upcoming remove rpc
message with the in-complete router into, according to [4].

[1] https://github.com/openstack/neutron/blob/master/neutron/db/l3_hamode_db.py#L546
[2] https://github.com/openstack/neutron/blob/master/neutron/agent/l3/ha_router.py#L82
[3] https://github.com/openstack/neutron/blob/master/neutron/agent/l3/agent.py#L512-L515
[4] https://github.com/openstack/neutron/blob/master/neutron/agent/l3/agent.py#L356

Change-Id: Iafdc4d68d4cb31d6699e87303d6e879f09d522d6
Closes-Bug: #1510757
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/neutron refs/changes/62/240662/8 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: raise Exception(_('Unable to process HA router %s without ' 'HA port') % self.router_id)
deleted_lines: LOG.error(_LE('Unable to process HA router %s without HA port'), self.router_id) return

subject: add validate check for update_port
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-12-02 06:17:14.000000000', 'files': ['neutron/tests/unit/plugins/ml2/test_plugin.py', 'neutron/plugins/ml2/plugin.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/neutron/commit/50583f12b05d2c0fc4a8d8733182dd157996df44', 'message': "add validate check for update_port

For LBaaS VIP port, its IP address is read only attribute, it
cannot be update to LBaaS API, but by neutron common command
'port-update', it could be. This should be invalid. Bug 1493688
is filed for this.

For router interface port, we can use 'port-update' to update
its device_id, which indeed will change the router_id this port
attaches to(even new device_id is not a router id). And we can
use 'router-port-list' to confirm. But this should be invalid,
for that will break data consistance between table Ports and
RouterPorts, record in the former one will have new device_id
while the later one will keep original device_id as router_id.
Bug 1408193 is filed for this.

This patch introduces a validate check method for update_port
to prevent two above cases happen.

Change-Id: I5f36fd216793e916fe8cd9ebe83ba5796a48f0a1
Closes-Bug: #1408193
Closes-Bug: #1493688
"}]
commit_message:
add validate check for update_port

For LBaaS VIP port, its IP address is read only attribute, it
cannot be update to LBaaS API, but by neutron common command
'port-update', it could be. This should be invalid. Bug 1493688
is filed for this.

For router interface port, we can use 'port-update' to update
its device_id, which indeed will change the router_id this port
attaches to(even new device_id is not a router id). And we can
use 'router-port-list' to confirm. But this should be invalid,
for that will break data consistance between table Ports and
RouterPorts, record in the former one will have new device_id
while the later one will keep original device_id as router_id.
Bug 1408193 is filed for this.

This patch introduces a validate check method for update_port
to prevent two above cases happen.

Change-Id: I5f36fd216793e916fe8cd9ebe83ba5796a48f0a1
Closes-Bug: #1408193
Closes-Bug: #1493688
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/neutron refs/changes/03/252203/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: def _validate_port_update_allowed(self, orig_port, port): lbaas_device_owner = [ const.DEVICE_OWNER_LOADBALANCER, const.DEVICE_OWNER_LOADBALANCERV2] if 'fixed_ips' in port: if ('device_owner' not in port and orig_port['device_owner'] in lbaas_device_owner): msg = _("Cannot update read-only attribute fixed-ip " "for %s port.") % orig_port['device_owner'] raise exc.BadRequest(resource='port', msg=msg) if (orig_port.get('device_owner') in const.ROUTER_INTERFACE_OWNERS and 'device_owner' not in port): if 'device_id' in port: msg = _("Cannot update device_id for router interface.") raise exc.BadRequest(resource='port', msg=msg) return True self._validate_port_update_allowed(port_db, attrs)

commit_message:
Improve log level in neutron sanity check

For the sake of checking configuration against system available
features, some of the exception messages using debug level,
here we can replace them by warning level.

Change-Id: I450f894b60694ad20ac8e93ada80150a3231b57c
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/neutron refs/changes/90/256190/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: LOG.exception(_LE("Exception while checking supported feature via " "%(command)s. %(Exception)s:"), {'command': full_args, 'Exception': e}) LOG.exception(_LE("Exception while checking minimal dnsmasq version. " "Exception: %s"), e) LOG.exception(_LE("Exception while checking for installed ebtables. " "Exception: %s"), e) LOG.exception(_LE("Exception while checking for installed ipset. " "Exception: %s"), e) LOG.exception(_LE("Exception while checking minimal dibbler version. " "Exception: %s"), e)
deleted_lines: LOG.debug("Exception while checking supported feature via " "command %s. Exception: %s", full_args, e) LOG.debug("Exception while checking minimal dnsmasq version. " "Exception: %s", e) LOG.debug("Exception while checking for installed ebtables. " "Exception: %s", e) LOG.debug("Exception while checking for installed ipset. " "Exception: %s", e) LOG.debug("Exception while checking minimal dibbler version. " "Exception: %s", e)

This is a debug patch to check the gate failures on SSHTimeOut.
The intent of this patch is to add some sort of self test with
in the agent to make sure that the path between the fip and
router namespace is connected and reachable.

Once we identify the gate failures with respect to FloatingIP

commit_message:
Debug patch to test the gate failures on SSHTimeOut

This is a debug patch to check the gate failures on SSHTimeOut.
The intent of this patch is to add some sort of self test with
in the agent to make sure that the path between the fip and
router namespace is connected and reachable.

Once we identify the gate failures with respect to FloatingIP
for DVR routers, this probe patch can be removed.

Change-Id: I1ed5c815fde66845f84d92382b6f07a9f443b393
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/neutron refs/changes/48/247748/5 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: LOG.debug("Floating IP rule added in router namespace " "for fixed ip: %s", fixed_ip) LOG.debug("Floating IP route added in fip namespace " "for fip_cidr: %s", fip_cidr) LOG.debug("Floating IP address advertisement notification " "sent from fip namespace: %s", floating_ip) # NOTE: Let us let us try to do some self-test to make # sure that the FIP is reachable. This is a just for debug # purpose and can be removed later. # Check if we can ping the private ip from the router namespace try: self._fip_path_validate(self.ns_name, fixed_ip, timeout=2, count=4) except Exception: LOG.debug("Private IP %(private_ip)s not reachable from " "router namespace %(namespace)s", {'private_ip': fixed_ip, 'namespace': self.ns_name}) # Check if we can ping the floating ip from the fip namespace try: self._fip_path_validate( fip_ns_name, floating_ip, timeout=2, count=4) except Exception: LOG.debug("Floating IP %(fip_ip)s not reachable from " "fip namespace %(namespace)s", {'fip_ip': floating_ip, 'namespace': fip_ns_name}) def _fip_path_validate(self, namespace, dest_ip, timeout=1, count=1): ipversion = netaddr.IPAddress(dest_ip).version ping_command = 'ping' if ipversion == 4 else 'ping6' ns_ip_wrapper = ip_lib.IPWrapper(namespace) ns_ip_wrapper.netns.execute([ping_command, '-c', count, '-W', timeout, dest_ip])

commit_message:
Fix missing parent start() call in RpcWorker.

Patch 5be613490deebf494f2ecbbcd8cb5dd0d6f5e1b3 erroneously removed this
line that is still needed which broke networking-ovn, at least.

Change-Id: I31981e905f892df474c57b45d3e70ebfbeeae1db
Signed-off-by: Russell Bryant <rbryant@redhat.com>
(cherry picked from commit 7b6fb800ced7c0b3f0be90d1c67d5ef58e58b82e)

commit_message:
Refactor _process_external_gateway in l3/router_info.py

The current logic in _process_external_gateway is a bit redundant
and hard to read. The refactor here is to clarify roles of ex_gw_port
vs self.ex_gw_port.

Change-Id: I2783d458b795ba392781503074d0abfef7223842
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/neutron refs/changes/75/271175/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: """Process the external gateway change This method will compare the new external gateway port with the old one, which is self.ex_gw_port. And do the add/update/remove job accordingly :param ex_gw_port: The new external gateway port :param pd: The PrefixDelegation of agent """ if ex_gw_port: interface_name = self.get_external_device_interface_name( ex_gw_port) elif self.ex_gw_port: interface_name = self.get_external_device_interface_name( self.ex_gw_port) # Process SNAT rules for new external gateway self._handle_router_snat_rules(ex_gw_port, interface_name)
deleted_lines: # TODO(Carl) Refactor to clarify roles of ex_gw_port vs self.ex_gw_port ex_gw_port_id = (ex_gw_port and ex_gw_port['id'] or self.ex_gw_port and self.ex_gw_port['id']) if ex_gw_port_id: interface_name = self.get_external_device_name(ex_gw_port_id) if ex_gw_port: elif not ex_gw_port and self.ex_gw_port: # Process SNAT rules for external gateway gw_port = self._router.get('gw_port') self._handle_router_snat_rules(gw_port, interface_name)

commit_message:
skip add_endpoint for endpoint not changed case

In tunnel_type.py, in method tunnel_sync, endpoint will
be queried by passed host and ip, and previous checking
in tunnel_sync will check queried endpoint with passed
host and ip in multiple cases, like whether ip and host
have changed or upgraded.

But for case which ip and host are not changed will not
be checked(which will happen when ovs-agent or ovs
restarted) previous logic will call add_endpoint again for
passed ip and host, and raise warning like
"Endpoint with ip X already exists" in
neutron-server log.

It doesn't make sense, since ip and host are not changed,
and we have queried DB twice, we don't need do another DB
operation and raise a warning.

Closes-bug: #1494570

Change-Id: I7e1eb3fca10f69f3fe3740447dc4216144fc2268
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/neutron refs/changes/59/222459/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # 5. If both passed host and tunnel ip can be found in DB, the # endpoint with (tunnel_ip, host) must already exist. This # may be caused by ovs-agent or ovs restart. tunnel = None elif (ip_endpoint and ip_endpoint.host == host): tunnel = ip_endpoint elif (host_endpoint and host_endpoint.ip_address == tunnel_ip): tunnel = host_endpoint if not tunnel: tunnel = driver.obj.add_endpoint(tunnel_ip, host)

commit_message:
Check ProcessMonitor running flag before checking processes

We have a testing issue, where process monitor attempts to
respawn processes even if we ordered it to stop.

This is due to the loop design, and the checking interval,
if the stop flag is set during a long check interval, the
processes will still be checked once again.

In this new loop the flag is checked right before attempting
to start a checking thread.

Change-Id: Ifb3d3b1d317f9cc372f69e21ab98a6db9b3cba11

commit_message:
Remove duplicated logic in get_subnet_for_dvr

In get_subnet_for_dvr, subnet_id will be extracted from parameter
fixed_ips if fixed_ips is not None. But indeed, its callers has
already extracted subnet_id from fixed_ips before get_subnet_for_dvr
is called, like:

  def _bind_distributed_router_interface_port(..):
      fixed_ip = fixed_ips[0]
      subnet_uuid = fixed_ip['subnet_id']
      ...
      subnet_info = self.plugin_rpc.get_subnet_for_dvr(
          self.context, subnet_uuid, fixed_ips=fixed_ips)

So it's duplicated and unnecessary to extract again.

Closes-Bug: #1531065
Change-Id: Ieca37c96ec002e9277bc5bc86be48a843c5142a4
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/neutron refs/changes/63/263563/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Fix help text for option min_l3_agents_per_router

The current help text incorrectly states that this option might be
set to 0, but looking at the code, that will indeed lead to an
error. Probably the text was wrongly copied from
max_l3_agents_per_router.

Change-Id: I999c21ec1170b09f0ffa18ec181ead19c15ee7a2
